_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Program 1 Risk Management Plan

Mandaree Pad

Williston Basin, WPX Energy, Inc.



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Montana Dakota Services operates a J-T plant designed to recover propane, butane and natural gasoline from gas prior to gathering and final treatment for WPX Energy, Inc. (WPX) at the Mandaree Pad.  This report provides the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the recovery skid system, pursuant to the requirements of the U.S. EPA RMP rule.



The system is designed to remove liquids from gas at the wellhead, having an inlet pressure between 150 and 400 psi.  The J-T valve system can generate temperatures as low as -20?F.  Montana Dakota Services uses this system to remove liquids from flared gases.  The portability of the unit allows it to easily be moved from site to site when flaring ceases.  The LPG storage tanks have an 18,000 gallon capacity. Montana Dakota Services will have two tanks onsite and the maximum fill for each tank is 14,400 gallons. The 28,800 gallons is equivalent to 164,448 lbs. of flammable liquids.



Under the authority of section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act, the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions require facilities that produce, handle, process, distribute, or store certain chemicals to develop a Risk Management Program, prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP), and submit the RMP to EPA. Covered facilities were initially required to comply with the rule in 1999, and the rule has been amended on several occasions since then, most recently in 2004. This facility is regulated under Title 40, Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68), more commonly known as the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. RMP plans must be prepared for processes that store in excess of the thresholds set forth by 40 CFR 68.130. For flammable liquids, the threshold is 10,000 lbs.  Montana Dakota Services can store approximately164,448 lbs. of LPG and exceeds 10,000 lbs. threshold, thus the facility is subject to the requirements of the Chemical Accident Preventi

on rule and must prepare a RMP.



LOCATION



The Mandaree Pad is located in the NW ? of the NW ? of section 30, Township 150N, Range 93W, Dunn County, North Dakota, on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation (FBIR).



Latitude: 47.789508, Longitude: -102.641048



DRIVING DIRECTIONS

Proceed in a Westerly direction from Mandaree, ND to Highway 22; turn right and proceed in a Northerly direction approximately 2.8 miles, turn right and proceed in a Easterly direction approximately 1.3 miles, turn left and proceed in a Northerly direction approximately 0.4 mile, turn right and proceed in a Easterly and then Northeasterly direction approximately 2 miles to the Mandaree Pad.



DISPERSION MODELING ANAYSIS WITH RMP*COMP



RMP*Comp: Results of Consequence Analysis

Scenario Summary

December 7, 2017



Chemical Name                    CAS Number    Quantity Released (pounds)

Butane                            106-97-8    37932

Ethane                             74-84-0    11041

Isobutane [Propane, 2-methyl]    75-28-5     11654

Isopentane [Butane, 2-methyl-]    78-78-4         9796

Methane                            74-82-8     225

Pentane                            109-66-0    20239

Propane                             74-98-6    73561



Threat type:      Flammable



Scenario type:  Worst-case



Release type:   Vapor Cloud Explosion

Estimated distance to 1 psi overpressure: 0.4 miles (0.7 kilometers)



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS: POPULATION AND ENVIRONMENT



After the distance to the flammable endpoint has been determined, the offsite impacts on population, public receptors, and environmental receptors should be analyzed as required by the RMP rule. The population within a circle centered at the point of release and a radius equal to the distance to the flammable endpoint should be estimated to two significant digits. In addition, all types of public receptors (schools, residences, hospitals, prisons, public recreation areas or arenas, major commercial or industrial areas) and environmental receptors (

national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, or refuges; federal wilderness areas) within this distance should be identified.



A field survey was used to estimate the potentially affected population within the distance to the flammable endpoint and to identify public receptors.  The survey showed that no population is within the 0.4 mile impact radius for the worst case release. The impact area on a map is demonstrated in appendix A. The types of public receptors and environmental receptors identified within the impact area are listed in Table 2-2.  Google Earth was used to find the public receptors within the impact radius. Additionally, no environmental receptors are impacted by the worst-case release scenario.
